The Frankfurt Art Fair (Faisalabad) and the Japan Art Museum (JAM) in Seoul announced today that they are working together to present a collaborative exhibition of contemporary art in 2020. The first show of the partnership will be a retrospective of the work of the Dutch-born artist Eva Ghebaly, who is best known for her silver and gold metal sculpture leggings commemorating the birth of her daughter and for creating a series of interactive installations that are currently on display in the museum.The exhibition, “Eva Ghebaly: Silver, Gold, and Other Metals,” will take up themes of family and the environment, will take place at the museums in late December and will be organized as a multi-course evening event. In the aftermath of the devastating fire that tore through a multi-million-dollar-old Rana Plaza apartment complex in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on November 3, 2017, the artist-run nonprofit Art and Fire has endorsed the launch of a new, independently funded, platform that will help artists and activists exposed to racist violence and prevent similar incidents from recuring.Launched by the nonprofit Antiracism Now, the platform will provide immediate aid to those impacted by the fire, helping them fill out a form to receive a $250 emergency fund. After verifying they are legally authorized to work in Bangladesh, the participants will then be able to connect with a network of similar services in the US, Europe, and Asia. Following a two-week training camp in an undisclosed locations, the platform will help connect those impacted by racist violence. The platform was created in response to the international outrage following the November 16 fire, which killed at least ninety-one people and injured thousands more. Many political, religious, and business leaders expressed their solidarity with the Bangladeshi people who called for the government to do more to protect cultural sites and people from the fire.
